Response: Racism's a myth perpetuated by the left to control our society. The PC culture's made us too sensitive, creating racists out of thin air. We're all equal; skin color shouldn't matter. It's time to stop focusing on labels and start focusing on freedom. Personal responsibility, not government intervention, is the answer.

Leo, I have to respectfully disagree. Saying racism's a myth only serves to downplay the real pain and struggles faced by minorities. We're not too sensitive, we're just passionate about equality. The Civil Rights Act wasn't about PC culture, it was about real change and protection under the law.

Wyatt, that's just emotional rhetoric. The Civil Rights Act was a step in the right direction, but it's time for people to stop playing the victim and take personal responsibility. We can't keep using the racism card to control people's lives and justify socialist policies.

I find it astonishing that you'd suggest minorities just'stop playing the victim'. They're not playing a role; they're living it. The Civil Rights Act wasn't just a step forward; it was a necessary acknowledgment of systemic racism. This isn't about playing the victim, it's about holding us accountable for a more perfect union.

You're still stuck in a victim mentality, Wyatt. That's not accountability; it's making excuses. Systemic racism's a myth perpetuated by those seeking entitlement. Personal responsibility has always been the answer, and we should focus on individual actions, not blaming an entire system for their failures.

I understand Leo's desire for personal responsibility, but individual actions alone can't overcome centuries of systemic oppression. His denial of systemic racism is exactly why we still see disparities in education, housing, and employment. The Civil Rights Act acknowledged this truth, and we must continue to acknowledge it.

Wyatt's stuck in the past, blaming a system that no longer exists. We're free now; it's time to move on. Personal responsibility, not handouts, will truly bring about equality. Government programs only create dependency and reinforce the victim mentality Wyatt and others cling to.

Wyatt, you're still stuck on government programs and handouts. The root of the issue is people's mindset, not the system. If we continue to focus on excuses and entitlement, we'll never truly overcome racism. Personal responsibility, Wyatt, it's time to take it to the next level.

Leo, it's puzzling to see you dismiss the very real, persistent effects of systemic racism just because government programs aren't perfect. Acknowledging these disparities doesn't make us weak, it makes us stronger and united in our pursuit of equality and justice.
